title: Efficient API Testing with Minor Usability Hiccups
body: As a QA engineer, I use Hoppscotch primarily for debugging REST APIs during development. Its simplicity in crafting requests and inspecting responses speeds up my workflow significantly. The real-time response preview and environment variable support are particularly helpful for managing different test scenarios. However, I occasionally find the UI a bit cluttered when juggling multiple tabs, and some advanced authentication methods are not as straightforward to configure as in other tools. Overall, Hoppscotch offers a reliable and lightweight solution for API testing, though it could benefit from improved navigation and expanded security features.

title: Good for quick API checks but limited for complex workflows

body: I used Hoppscotch mainly for debugging REST APIs during development. The interface is straightforward and quick to get started with, which makes basic testing easy. However, it falls short when you need complex scenarios like chaining requests or advanced auth workflows. Also, the lack of built-in support for automated test runs in CI pipelines limits its usefulness for continuous testing. Overall, it’s a decent tool for quick checks but not robust enough for serious backend debugging or integration testing.

title: Pretty handy but could use some polish
body: As a junior backend engineer, I use Hoppscotch mainly for debugging APIs during development. It’s great for quickly sending requests and checking responses without spinning up Postman. However, I’ve run into a few bugs with saving collections, which gets annoying when working on multiple services. Also, the UI feels a bit clunky and inconsistent at times. Overall, it’s a decent tool if you need a lightweight alternative, but it’s not quite ready to replace more polished API clients for me.

title: Good for basic API testing, but could be smoother
body: As a junior backend engineer, I use Postman mainly to debug APIs during development. It’s pretty straightforward to send requests and check responses, which helps me catch issues early. However, I find the UI a bit cluttered and sometimes slow, especially when I’m running multiple tests in a collection. The learning curve for more advanced features is steeper than I expected, which can be frustrating when trying to automate tests for CI pipelines. Overall, it’s decent for simple tasks but feels a bit heavyweight and clunky for everyday use.

title: Efficient API Testing with Minor UI Quirks
body: As a QA Engineer, I use Hoppscotch primarily for debugging APIs during development and verifying endpoints in our CI pipeline. Its lightweight interface and quick request setup make it easier to test various HTTP methods without switching tools. I appreciate the ability to save and organize requests, which streamlines repetitive testing. However, the UI can feel a bit cluttered when handling multiple tabs simultaneously, occasionally slowing down my workflow. Despite this, its open-source nature and responsiveness outweigh these minor issues, making it a reliable addition to my testing toolkit.

title: Super handy for debugging APIs!
body: As a junior backend engineer, I find Insomnia incredibly easy to use when I need to test and debug APIs. The interface is clean and makes it simple to organize requests and inspect responses. I especially like how I can save different environments, which speeds up my workflow between dev and staging. It's been a reliable tool for running quick tests without having to spin up the entire frontend. Overall, it’s boosted my productivity and confidence in API handling.

title: Great for quick API testing
body: As a junior backend engineer, I find Hoppscotch super handy when debugging APIs. Its interface is clean and easy to navigate, which makes setting up requests fast and painless. I especially like how I can save collections and share them with my team. The only thing I wish it had was better support for automated tests integrated into CI pipelines, but for manual API checks, it’s solid and reliable. Overall, a great tool to keep in your dev toolkit.
